text: I did a snow tool for a place I was working a few years ago. Its a useful thing and something a lot of studios would have or potentially want. While I think it would be an interesting approach to make a tool that takes in to account real world science, I'm not sure it would be very artist friendly. The artist would have to already have the knowledge of how a change in atmosphere or temperature would effect the look of the simulation. An artist is typically given a reference or a shot plate to match, so in the case of snow, would an artist be able to look at this reference and figure out what the temperature of the ground and air was? Also I would maybe say that wind in general is probably a greater contributor to the final look of snow that the general atmospheric conditions. But it is an interesting idea, I dont actually know how temp changes or moisture changes affect the look of snow. There is a great blog that I go to almost daily that you might enjoy if you're in to that stuff...

text: The Amtrack slow mo you sent is amazing. So much stuff going on there. Fast moving collisions, chunks of snow, snow sprays, and probably some volume kind of stuff. There is a lot to work with there. Also the train in general could be replaced with almost anything else. The other thing I love about that ref, is the people getting hit by the snow. Not to say that you should incorporate people in to your concept, but having the snow react with something else in the environment.

That being said, one thing to be careful of there is getting bogged down by simulation times. Since there is a lot of stuff going on might be best to think about doing stuff in stages. Like do the biggest chunks of snow first then running that through secondary and tertiary sims afterwards. Its always best to work as low res as you can at first, *fail fast,* and get basic interactions working first, if that makes sense.
Ok maybe going back to your first idea for a sec. Maybe instead of coming up with a tool that used real world science to create snow, maybe do something like that for air?
you could then apply that to any other kind of simulation you might want to have. Ash, smoke, snow, rain. I recently saw a realtime tool that does something like this, let me go find that real quick.
